Aussie Banks - October 2018

  • Home
  • Portfolio
  • Blog
  • Contact

Posted on 26th October 2018

Welcome to a very different article from usual. This time I'll be sharing with you the results of my overly enthusiastic research about Australian banks, and which ones are best for you.
I have no affiliation with any of them, and I do not use all of them.
I hope you find my categories and selection of criteria to focus on useful as they depart from the traditional ones and focus more on the... human benefits, such as convenience, as well as raw stats.

Just the best savings interest - UBank

The biggest number, at the top of the spreadsheet - 2.87% p.a.. Savings + Transaction Accounts

  • PDS - savings
  • PDS - transaction

  • Interest: 2.87% - Best of the best.
  • Requirements: Reasonable - deposit $200/month. Withdrawals are allowed. If not met, 1.81%.
  • Transaction: Meh - only "useful" feature is sweep which automatically takes money from your savings if necessary.
  • Fees: $0/0% in most common areas, including overseas transactions. Fees on Australian ATMs not refunded.
  • ATMs: Stick to the free Australian Big Bank ATMs or get burned. Interestingly, rediATMs will no longer be free for January 2019.
  • Bank@Post: Nope. Very disappointing.
  • # limit per customer: One combo of savings and transaction - rather disappointing.
  • $ limit: $200k.

Damn nice - ME Bank

Close to being "raw stats best". Damn good everyday features is what makes the deal. Online Savings Account

  • PDS - savings
  • PDS - transaction
  • PDS - fees

  • Interest: 2.85% - Awesome.
  • Requirements: Reasonable - Tag & go once per week. Withdrawals are allowed. If not met, 1.30%.
  • Transaction: Free ATMs in Australia.
  • Fees: $0/0% in most common areas. Overseas transactions are $4 + 2.3% of AUD value.
  • ATMs: Refund on Australian ATM fees within 30 days.
  • Bank@Post: Yes, on transaction account.
  • # limit per customer: Multiple (might have limits on interest?)
  • $ limit: $250k.

One stop shop - ING

If you can't be bothered dealing with multiple banks, ING is probably the best deal. Savings Maximiser + Orange Everyday

  • PDS - savings
  • PDS - transaction
  • PDS - fees

  • Interest: 2.80% - Awesome.
  • Requirements: Pushing it - deposit $1000/month, 5 card transactions / month. Withdrawals are allowed. If not met, 1.00%, and ATM fees not refunded.
  • Transaction: Free ATMs anywhere and everywhere.
  • Fees: $0/0% in most common areas, if you meet above requirements. Else, ATM fees not refunded, $2.50 + 2.5% for international.
  • ATMs: Refund on all ATM fees within 30 days if above requirements met.
  • Bank@Post: Yes, on transaction account.
  • # limit per customer: Multiple (might have limits on interest?)
  • $ limit: $100k.

Unconditional high interest - MOVE

Sometimes you just want a "set and forget" solution. MOVE is it. Express Saver

  • PDS - savings

  • Interest: 2.20% - Great, given lack of conditions.
  • Requirements: As long as you can open it, you get the full 2.20%!
  • Transaction: Don't bother.
  • Fees: Make sure you don't touch their transaction accounts, and you should be good to go.
  • ATMs: Big banks or just transfer funds to a decent transaction account first.
  • Bank@Post: Yes, no worries.
  • # limit per customer: Unknown.
  • $ limit: Unknown.

Unconditional low fees - Macquarie

You want no fees and no conditions? Macquarie may be the closest you can get. Macquarie Transaction Account

  • PDS - transaction
  • PDS - fees

  • Interest: It's a transaction account. You still want interest... alright, it's 1.10% p.a. for over $5k.
  • Requirements: Nothin'.
  • Transaction: No fees, no conditions.
  • Fees: No fees in Australia, that's for sure. Fees charged by international bodies may not be refunded.
  • ATMs: No ATM fees in Australia, only ATM operator's fee overseas.
  • Bank@Post: Nope. Need to use another bank to transfer funds.
  • # limit per customer: Unknown.
  • $ limit: N/A - over $1 million

Conclusion

Always do your own research, I take no responsibility etc.

I hope you found this somewhat useful.

Please refer to this awesome spreadsheet for savings account information: Whirlpool AU Bank Account Comparison
